## The effects of domestic grazing on the NBR semi-natural grasslands and heathlands

**(1) Domestic grazing promotes ecosystem service synergies across the whole agro-ecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (paper II, paper IV)...** - Regardless of the management or the production system, the grazing fields were characterised by high plant diversity (@fig-grazingR1 A) [@hamrePlantSpeciesRichness2010] and supported the delivery of multiple ecosystem services (**paper II**, **paper IV**) [@kremenEcosystemServicesBiologically2012]. 
Outfields were the most heterogeneous and species-rich habitats, with a lower carrying capacity compensated by higher contribution to carbon storage and water regulation services (**paper IV**) [@huStructuralCharacteristicsMoss2023; @quinCallunaVulgarisdominatedUpland2015]. 
In infields, nectar resource indicator and forage resource indicator were positively correlated (@fig-grazingR1 B), but only the former significantly increased with vascular plant species richness (**paper II**) [@heglandRelationshipsDensityDiversity2006]. 
Most studies investigating the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery in agro-ecosystems converge to acknowledge the evidence of a virtuous cascade under low-intensity farming, where higher diversity levels support a wider range of ecosystem services [@leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022; @schilsPermanentGrasslandsEurope2022; @wragePhytodiversityTemperatePermanent2011]. 
The pollination service shows a quite intuitive example of direct positive effects of plant taxonomic and functional richness on the amount, stability and plurality of pollinator food resource, resulting in a more active, more abundant and more diverse community of pollinators [@balfourTradeoffPollinatorwildflowerDiversity2025; @goulnikFloralTraitFunctional2020; @heglandRelationshipsDensityDiversity2006]. 
An exception to these generally synergetic interactions is the complex relationship between biodiversity and provisioning services [@leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022]: while plant diversity enhances forage nutritional quality [@jerrentrupDiverseSwardsMixedgrazing2020; @seitherSwardCompositionGrazer2012; @spehnEcosystemEffectsBiodiversity2005], increasing both species richness and forage production can only be compatible up to a certain threshold of management intensity beyond which competition and grazing pressure increase the dominance of fewer species [@brunProductivitybiodiversityRelationshipVaries2019; @schulzTradeoffsGrasslandPlant2024]. 
For nectar and forage resources to be positively correlated in the infields of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, it could be assumed that the current grazing management maintains the biodiversity-productivity balance in a tight win-win space independently of the type of agronomic production [@balfourTradeoffPollinatorwildflowerDiversity2025; @gongBiodiversityYieldTradeoffs2022; @ravettoenriBiodiversityfriendlyRotationalGrazing2017] (see Discussion in **paper II**). 
At the same time though, the lower performance of semi-natural grasslands into other regulating services compared with coastal and subalpine heathlands highlights that at least a certain extent of trade-offs is inherent to single agricultural habitats, and as such ensuring the multifunctionality of agro-ecological systems requires to rely on multiple, complementary land uses [@kremenLandscapesThatWork2018] (see Discussion in **paper IV**).

![(A) Distribution of plant species richness across the 42 study sites of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve and (B) Correlation between the forage resource value and the nectar resource value in the semi-natural grasslands.](illustrations/NBR_ResultGrazingR1.png){#fig-grazingR1}

**(2) ...while rotational prescribed burning locally enhances functional diversity and contributes to the regional heterogeneity of coastal heathlands (paper I, paper IV)...** - The Hopøyna beetle community showed different activity on pioneer and mature heath patches according to the species' preferences in moisture and vegetation cover (**paper I**): recently burnt patches were characterised by higher proportions of xerophilous and sun-loving species, while mature patches showed higher proportions of strict hygrophilous species [@morettiFireinducedTaxonomicFunctional2010; @schirmelResponseCarabidBeetles2011]. 
Fire reduced patch alpha diversity but without significantly increasing beta-diversity, contrary to previous findings [@bargmannEffectsPrescribedBurning2015; @brunbjergDisturbanceDryCoastal2015]. 
At the regional level though, coastal heathlands showed the highest between-site divergence compared with subalpine heathlands and grasslands (**paper IV**), suggesting that management by prescribed burning on three sites out of five rather tends to increase ecosystem heterogeneity [@velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014]. 
Atlantic heathlands are particularly vulnerable habitats as they depend on low-intensive, small-scale production systems which do not ensure the economic viability of the farms in the current globalised, highly competitive agricultural context [@hernandez-morcilloPriorityQuestionsScience2017]. 
Norwegian farmers generally show willingness in preserving the cultural landscape but there are practical limitations to maintain the management on remote areas [@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014; @kvakkestadNorwegianFarmersPerspectives2015], and even more so regarding the practice of prescribed burning which requires specific skills and dedicated training as the legacy from previous generation has mostly disappeared over time [@lundbergAustevollChangingCoastal1991].
Public support is usually motivated by the conservation interest of semi-natural heathlands as red-listed habitats [@hovstadKystlyngheiSeminaturligNorsk2018], but there are still considerable knowledge gaps regarding the effect of fire on arthropod taxa especially, despite their strong potential as bioindicators (see Discussion in **paper I**) [@rittlTraditionalNorwegianFarming2025; @yekwayoOnlyMultitaxonStudies2018], and on the delivery of ecosystem services, such as for instance carbon sequestration [@kopittkeAgeManagedHeathland2013; @liLongtermTemporalPatterns2023] (see Discussion in **paper IV**), that will be critical to address for ensuring the continuity of traditional prescribed burning on coastal areas [@walmsleyEnsuringLongtermProvision2021].

![Rotational prescribed burning tends to enhance ecological heterogeneity within and between coastal outfields: (A) Constrained ordination (CCA) of the composition of beetle assemblages according to the year of burn in Hopøyna coastal heathland, with pioneer patches on the left and mature patches on the right (from **paper I**) and (B) Hierarchical clustering of the sheep-grazed fields of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve according to biomass, diversity and soil indicators, with coastal outfields (black circles) on the right (from **paper IV**).](illustrations/NBR_ResultGrazingR2.png){#fig-grazingR2}

**(3) ...but the independent effects of livestock type and field management on the structure and composition of semi-natural grasslands are either marginal or yet to be clearly identified (paper II, paper III).** - We observed higher cover of Poaceae under cattle grazing (**paper II**) (@fig-grazingR3S C) and seemingly higher cover of cryptogams under sheep grazing (**paper II**, **paper III**) (@fig-grazingR3S B), but contrary to expectations there was no sign of grazer selectivity on forb cover (**paper II**) (@fig-grazingR3S D) [@tothLivestockTypeMore2016].
Results from **paper III** were particularly inconclusive as none of the outcomes from the canonical correlation analyses and redundancy analyses were consistent with each other regarding the effect of grazing management on dominant assemblages or fine-scale environment.
The impact of domestic grazing on grassland communities is particularly challenging to assess in observational studies as it results from the interaction of multiple and potentially contradicting mechanisms [@wragePhytodiversityTemperatePermanent2011], which can be alleviated or accentuated by the management intensity (e.g. fertilisation) [@sollenbergerGrasslandManagementAffects2019] and the local environment (e.g. topography, water availability) [@hesterForagingBehaviourSheep1999].
In the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, both the low intensity of the grazing pressure and the versatility of the rotational management amplify context-dependency and variability between sites [@aldayEffectsLongtermRemoval2021; @bohnStrengthsKSelectionShape2014; @conradiResourceAvailabilityDetermines2017] (see Discussion in **paper III**), thus blurring the partition of variance between independent interactions such as grazer selectivity [@cuchillohilarioForageSelectivityCattle2018; @pakemanLongTermImpacts2019].
As such, the lower bryophyte/graminoid ratio observed in cattle-grazed fields could be explained by either an increase in trampling pressure [@ludvikovaLongTermDefoliation2014] or a more intensive use of artificial fertiliser [@kiddImpacts120Years2017], but we found no supporting correlations with bulk density or nutrient concentration to support any of these hypotheses (**paper III**).
Instead, as the composition of the dominant plant assemblages was primarily affected by the inherent productivity of the sites (**paper III**) [@losvikHayMeadowCommunities1993], these differences may indirectly reflect the farmer decision-making in allocating livestock type according to the agronomic potential of the fields (see Discussion in **paper II**).
Overall, we could not identify the specific drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery in the semi-natural grasslands of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, which is to be imputed at least partially to the limitations of our study design.
We thus recommend a more thorough analysis of plant and especially arthropod communities [@losvikHayMeadowCommunities1993; @lyonsImpactsContrastingConservation2017], but under the condition of revising the methodological framework to adapt both the local environmental context and the rotational management dynamics [@germanRelationshipsMultipleAspects2017; @sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019].

# Methodological considerations and perspectives

## Heterogeneity and spatio-temporal variability in the Nordhordland agro-ecological system

The small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve result from mutual interactions between a strong environmental context, characterised by complex cross-scale processes between the overlapping oceanity and elevation gradients and multiple levels of topographical heterogeneity [@graaeStayGoHow2018; @zhangDisentanglingEffectsClimate2024], and the grazing animal, as the most direct combination of mechanistic pressures from the bite level of individuals to the whole field occupation by the flock [@parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003], mediated across space and time by the farmer which aims to maintain the socioeconomic performance and sustainability of the farm [@mcginlayThreatAbandonmentSocioecological2017].
Even if predictable to some extent, these interactions still involve a high level of stochasticity stemming not only from the environmental variation but also from the farmer and livestock decision-making, which does not rely on an absolute rationalisation of resource exploitation [@nuthallIntuitiveWorldFarmers2012; @rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004].
An example of successive and co-dependent interactions between the environment, the field, the farmer and the livestock within the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve could be as follow:

(a) The climate and landform determine patterns of habitat productivity at regional scales, limiting land use and the exploitation of forage resources [@fridleyLongerGrowingSeasons2016; @huangAirTemperatureOptima2019];
(b) According to these environmental conditions as well as socioeconomic criteria including land ownership, farm structure and agronomic production, the farmer frames the intensity (e.g. flock size) and spatio-temporal dynamics (e.g. field area, occupation period) of the grazing pressure across fields [@hylandFactorsInfluencingDairy2018; @robertProcessesAdaptationFarm2016];
(c) Within the field unit, the topography and the farmer management (e.g. fertilisation, prescribed burning) determine nutrient availability and biomass production [@maestreAmountPatternGrassland2007], which in turns affect the livestock movement and foraging strategies [@hesterForagingBehaviourSheep1999; @wallisdevriesImportanceScalePatchiness1999];
(d) The grazing process initiates an energy cycle between the livestock, which removes biomass and redistributes nutrients through urine and dung, and the field, whose recovery potential depends from the resource availability (nutrients, water) and the intensity of the disturbance (foraging, trampling) [@mayelHowDoesGrassland2021; @sittersImpactsBrowsingGrazing2019];
(e) From the field capacity to respond to the grazing pressure over time, the farmer interferes on the grazer x field interaction by adapting the grazing pressure (e.g. flock size, field area) or the nutrient supply (e.g. fertilisation) [@nuthallIntuitiveWorldFarmers2012; @robertProcessesAdaptationFarm2016];
(f) The versatility of the management and the movement of livestock across multiple grazing fields drives a subtle but continuous renewal of the landscape mosaic over the years [@parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003].

This complex multi-interactivity generates particularly high levels of both inherent and induced variability, which were not explicitly accounted for in our choices of study design and analyses and were therefore only poorly addressed in the different papers.
First, we essentially approached the environmental context of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve as a broad and unidirectional west-east gradient while overlooking the multiple levels of spatial heterogeneity induced by the diversity of fjord shape, direction, width and steepness [@bennieInfluenceSlopeAspect2006; @graaeStayGoHow2018; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
In **paper III** especially, it would have been relevant to include at least one measure of topographic complexity (e.g. variance of elevation or slope, see @yuMultiscaleComparisonTopographic2015) in the regional-scale explanatory set, which only included site elevation as a landform-related variable.
Second, despite the nested sampling design of our ecological study we did not attempt to investigate grazing management according to the sward patchiness driven by livestock foraging [@tonnGrazingInducedPatchiness2019].
In **paper II ** for instance we could have compared the within-field variation of forage and nectar resource values according to grazer types [@duquetteSpatiallyDiscreteDisturbance2022], or in **paper III** we could have assessed the explanatory power of sward heterogeneity in the fine-scale environment set in relation to grazing management or plant and beetle assemblages [@ravettoenriBiodiversityfriendlyRotationalGrazing2017]. 
Third, the versatility of the rotational management, particularly showing through the inconsistency of occupation time and flock size across the season, caused practical challenges for quantifying individual factors such as stocking density at the field level (see Discussion in **paper III**).
This led us to question not only the accuracy but also the relevance of such field-level assessments which can only poorly capture the spatio-temporal dynamics driven by the rotations and the associated mosaic effect, similarly to how the response of beetles to fire at the patch level in **paper I** may not be representative of the effect of rotational prescribed burning on the beetle community (see Discussion in **paper I**) [@tammeEnvironmentalHeterogeneitySpecies2010; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
Lastly, higher indicator sensitivity may have been necessary to capture community responses to grazing management under low disturbance regime, especially for arthropod taxa which were investigated at the rather coarse taxonomic resolution, respectively family-level for beetles in **paper III** and order-level for mesofauna in **paper IV** [@daoudiCompositionPhenologyBeetle2022].
We should have anticipated the considerable level of time, resource and expertise for detailed morphological identification and could have envisioned other approaches during the project planning, such as for instance setting a collaboration with experts or rely on novel DNA methods [@geisenMethodologicalFrameworkEmbrace2019; @sigsgaardEnvironmentalDNAMetabarcoding2021].

## Optimising the study design towards trans-disciplinary farm-level assessments of multifunctionality

Ultimately, ecological research has a role in ensuring the productivity, functionality and resilience of agricultural habitats on the long-term by providing actionable knowledge and concrete perspectives for the implementation and the preservation of sustainable management practices [@altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004; @gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019].
However, for this knowledge to be representative, comprehensive and applicable in consideration of the local context and the involved stakeholders, research standards should be revised to aim for holistic approaches based on robust, spatially-explicit but also flexible methodological frameworks, favouring resolution over replication and providing analytical guidelines rather than ready-made indicators [@germanRelationshipsMultipleAspects2017; @sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019; @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017].
Concretely, addressing the inherent variance in small-scale grazing systems not as a bias to control but as the most determinant factor [@sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019] requires to shift the focus of the analysis towards the core unit structuring the agro-ecological system, namely the farm [@cloughFieldSizesFuture2020; @deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995; @wilsonWeakStrongMultifunctionality2008].
This choice implies to take a landscape perspective [@leprovostContrastingResponsesBelowground2021; @leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022; @tscharntkeLandscapePerspectivesAgricultural2005], in which spatial arrangement and connectivity materialise not only as tangible, ecological patches and corridors [@baileyInfluenceThematicResolution2007; @evjuSpatialConfigurationMatters2016] but also as energy and disturbance flows driven by the decision-making of the farmer [@deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995].
With complex interactions involved between the different agro-ecological structures (e.g. rural community, farm, field, paddock), the consideration of multiple spatial scales is however crucial to identify the key processes driving variance in agro-ecological systems [@nashDiscontinuitiesCrossScale2014; @petersCrossScaleInteractions2007], and by extent disentangling the respective influences of the environmental gradient and the management [e.g. @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017; @redlichDisentanglingEffectsClimate2022].
The determination of suitable indicators will require a more thorough investigation of grassland and heathland communities, as optimal surrogates of biodiversity response to grazing management have yet to be determined [@bucherBiodiversityLowintensityPastures2016; @neffCrossscaleEffectsLand2019].
Priority should be given to taxa contributing to key ecosystem functions [@balSelectingIndicatorSpecies2018], but we advise caution for selecting target groups based on fuzzy definition, such as for instance "dung beetle", unless their dominance in the local context has been confirmed (see Discussion in **paper III**).
We particularly recommend to dedicate more attention to the soil compartment, as scientific evidence on the crucial implication of soil organisms for multifunctionality accumulates while highlighting that considerable knowledge gaps still remain [@bardgettBelowgroundBiodiversityEcosystem2014; @degraaffEffectsAgriculturalIntensification2019; @wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019].

Last but not least, ensuring the pertinence, applicability and accessibility of ecological research in agricultural systems requires the active involvement of the farmers as knowledge-holders, decision-makers and managers through processes of co-production [@bennettLinkingBiodiversityEcosystem2015; @jagerPathwaysImplementationEvidence2020; @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017].
Trans-disciplinary research is still a vast field to explore [@lacombeDesigningAgroecologicalFarming2018], but several principles should be respected to ensure inclusive, open, transparent and equitable collaboration on the long-term [@stringerUnpackingParticipationAdaptive2006].
First, farmer knowledge built from empirical, context-specific and community-based learning, by essence complementary to the fundamental, generalised and discipline-based academic knowledge of scientists, is indispensable for a comprehensive understanding of land use patterns in the agro-ecological system [@altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004; @nuthallIntuitiveWorldFarmers2012; @shiSocialInteractionEffect2021].
We ourselves directly witnessed the considerable capacity of the farmers, and more particularly the elders, to recollect quite precisely the management history of not only their own fields but also the surrounding agricultural landscape, up to 100 years in the past [@ianniRevitalizingTraditionalEcological2015].
Second, research concepts should be discussed, adapted and validated over a common understanding between farmers and scientists [@dickStakeholdersPerspectivesOperationalisation2018; @dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001], with priority given to the ones already mostly assimilated in policy-making such as landscape multifunctionality [@bjorkhaugMultifunctionalAgriculturePolicy2008; @kremenLandscapesThatWork2018].
For instance @lamarqueHowEcosystemServices2014 showed that even though farmers were familiar with the concept of ecosystem services and were able to integrate them in their decision-making, they still gained from raised awareness on the least known regulating services (i.e. nitrogen leaching, carbon storage).
Lastly, farmer values should be thoroughly identified and discriminated to reflect the disparity of circumstances within the rural community [@bernuesSeeingNorthernEuropean2016; @busckFarmersLandscapeDecisions2002].
The pragmatic approach of farmers driven by the material consideration of the farm management as well as constraints of socio-economic performance is essential for a realistic feasibility assessment of potential agro-ecological pathways [@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018].

## Perspectives for the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve

We confirmed that biodiversity conservation and ecosystem service delivery in the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve depended from the continuous management of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands across the whole west-east gradient [@hamrePlantSpeciesRichness2010; @johansenCeasedGrazingManagement2019; @velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014].
Current stakes in Western Norway are thus to ensure the viability of farming, especially in remote areas, and supporting the diversity of farm models [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006; @potthoffNorwegianLowintensityOvine2023], by upgrading public subsidies schemes or adding value to the production of commodities associated with cultural heritage such as rustic breeds (e.g. *Gammel Norsk Sau*) or traditional goat summer farms [@asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020; @kvakkestadNorwegianFarmersPerspectives2015].
In this context, the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve has a key role for initiating and mediating knowledge co-production between farmers, scientists and policy-makers for the experimentation of innovative pathways towards multifunctional and resilient food production systems [@jagerPathwaysImplementationEvidence2020; @lacombeDesigningAgroecologicalFarming2018].
If our ecological study assumed a relatively standard, non-participatory research framework, we still aimed to bring a modest contribution to the development of trust and mutual understanding between farmers and scientists: as a token of gratitude for granting access and sharing their knowledge, we delivered a personalised pamphlet to each farmer summarising the biological and environmental data collected on their fields.
In parallel, we produced a generalised version of the pamphlet based on the whole dataset for advertising research achievements with the Biosphere Reserve framework to raise interest and awareness among the general public and potential partners.
With the TradMod project as the first stepping stone [see @cusensParticipatoryMappingReveals2022; @cusensIntegrationMattersCombining2023], the team associated with the UNESCO Chair on Sustainable Heritage and Environmental Management strives to take the lead in trans-disciplinary research for maximising the potential of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve as a model area for sustainable land use.
